@PrestonLewis8 @besttrousers @RadioFreeTom It wasn't the individual leverage that was the systemic problem. It was the leverage among financial intermediaries.

@RadioFreeTom @besttrousers With tons of leverage, it takes very little credit deterioration to bring things tumbling down. It was the proliferation of derivatives that was at the heart of the leverage. Total bet amount on a horse race isn't limited by the number of horses in race or even number of races
@RadioFreeTom @besttrousers Derivatives and leverage

@RadioFreeTom @kellydraper Wld be nice if others' terrible financial decisions had no effect on ppl who act responsibly. But that's not the world we live in. @besttrousers @RadioFreeTom The guy smoking in bed 'deserves' to have his house burn down. But if the firemen don't come out and save it, there's likely a lot of innocent collateral damage
@besttrousers @RadioFreeTom True.
@kellydraper @RadioFreeTom Basically, yes. The reigning ideology trusted markets too much. There's an optimal degree of trust and we all went too far

@kellydraper @RadioFreeTom Yes. Private sector excess (which we see at the end of every cycle) that this time went global and went deep. The Efficient Market fantasy that banks were smart & incented enough to regulate themselves was the fatal conceit. And both parties were guilty of believing this
@HalfAgain @RadioFreeTom How much is "more"? And how do you arrive at that number?

@RadioFreeTom Yes. From the borrowers to the originators to the banks to the end investors: greed at every link in the chain. And it was all private sector. The spin that it was Fannie&Freddie&Fed was ideological subterfuge

@HalfAgain @RadioFreeTom Sad that more ppl don't know that Treasury turned a profit on the programs.  They received both warrants and step up coupons. Structure was v smart and didn't require handing banks over to Nancy Pelosi and Mike Capuano. So much misinformation fed so much rage.
@RadioFreeTom Also, many are angry at things that weren’t true or didn’t happen. And these turned out to be costly distortions.
@RadioFreeTom The hardest problems usually have no good solutions; only degrees of bad.

@RadioFreeTom Plus “bailout” used way too loosely. Taxpayer ended up making money bc of how Geithner structured the mechanisms. And the loose talk led to misguided anger and outrage that we’re paying for today.

@RadioFreeTom It was the least bad way. Financial system locked up once banks stopped trusting each other. Fed was the only thing that kept us from lining up in PJs in front of ATMs praying there was cash left. Collateral damage wld have been massive.

@gianlucac1 @gusbaratta @RajaKorman @sole24ore @zingales_it @ricpuglisi What you're saying is Italy's has--relative to others--made bad choices, can't compete, and can't fix. So why keep the others' FX rate?
@ricpuglisi @gusbaratta @RajaKorman @sole24ore @zingales_it Not debating effect of FX rate on productivity. Saying a flex FX allows whatever the lvl of productivity to find a price
@gianlucac1 @gusbaratta @RajaKorman @sole24ore @zingales_it @ricpuglisi Mi dispiaci. Nonostante le buone intenzioni, l'euro e' fallito. Il vero prob e' che l'uscita eventuale sara' molto doloroso

@ricpuglisi @gianlucac1 @gusbaratta @RajaKorman @sole24ore @zingales_it Econometrics for macro deosn't work that well. Most practitioners have come 2accept this. But, don't worry. Plenty of ppl try. Check the IMF
@ricpuglisi @gianlucac1 @gusbaratta @RajaKorman @sole24ore @zingales_it Econometric answers are IMO vastly overrated, but I'm sure you will find lots of it if you look

@gianlucac1 @gusbaratta @RajaKorman @sole24ore @zingales_it @ricpuglisi No. I mean, there might be some, but that's not the point. Pt is whatever your lvl of relative productivity, flex FX helps price it right

@RajaKorman @gianlucac1 @gusbaratta @sole24ore @zingales_it @ricpuglisi Realistically, prob not going to get stronger no matter what. But is the South at a bigger disadvantage w German or Milanese FX rate?
@ricpuglisi @gusbaratta @RajaKorman @sole24ore @zingales_it But check the IMF research dept. They have tons of good work on these issues
@ricpuglisi @gusbaratta @RajaKorman @sole24ore @zingales_it Look at Italy's own history with the SME and every other band. Didn't (and can't) fix the structural probs but improved external imbalances

@gianlucac1 @gusbaratta @RajaKorman @sole24ore @zingales_it @ricpuglisi The old hard-money saw "can't deval your way to prosperity" doesn't tell you what you shld do if you r pegged at a rate that is choking you

@gianlucac1 @gusbaratta @RajaKorman @sole24ore @zingales_it @ricpuglisi Brazil 2002. Korea 1997, list is endless. But it's not the deval really; it's having a ccy that reflects Italy's productivity, not Germany's

@gusbaratta @RajaKorman @sole24ore @zingales_it @ricpuglisi L-T fix, in sense that repricing of productivity differential is constant (albeit imprecise at any pt in time). Distrib issues can b managed
@pdmsero @RajaKorman @gusbaratta @sole24ore @zingales_it They've tried adjustable. They tried fixed. Issues have never been addressed. Why cling to a bad system b/c of fear of 2nd order incentives?
@RajaKorman @gusbaratta @sole24ore @zingales_it They've always been there tho. Been exposed basically since Garibaldi--okay, but you get my point
@gusbaratta @RajaKorman @sole24ore @zingales_it @ricpuglisi This much v true. Leaving wld be very painful. And few proponents of it are honest abt this. But "deval won't fix Italy's probs" also wrong
@RajaKorman @gusbaratta @sole24ore @zingales_it I run into "but an adjustable currency wont fix X or Y", which IMO is poor argument. Fixes in that it allows repricing of them
@RajaKorman @gusbaratta @sole24ore @zingales_it But an adjustable currency would allow for continuous repricing the many things that need fixing but may or may not ever be addressed

@MayankSeksaria @michaelsantoli @BullandBaird @conorsen Yeah, was just making analytical point that the case for vol selling as driver is stronger if spread has compressed
@MayankSeksaria @michaelsantoli @BullandBaird @conorsen In what way do today's products drive vol differently from other structured products?
@MayankSeksaria @michaelsantoli @BullandBaird @conorsen No. Saying vol selling doesn't drive down realized vol as much as it does the implied. So if spread ~constant, vol sellers not main driver
@MayankSeksaria @michaelsantoli @BullandBaird @conorsen Same dynamic: the selling takes place in the implieds, realizeds need not follow
@MayankSeksaria @michaelsantoli @BullandBaird @conorsen This is the main point here. Not making commentary on market, rather how to think abt the implied-realized spread
@MayankSeksaria @michaelsantoli @BullandBaird @conorsen The spread tho is best clue as to whether it's primarily vol selling (srepad compression) or potentially complacency (no spread compression)
@MayankSeksaria @michaelsantoli @BullandBaird @conorsen Sometimes they even cross
@MayankSeksaria @michaelsantoli @BullandBaird @conorsen In the past when I've seen systematic vol selling (CTAs or Marco HF in ccy space) you'd see implieds come in a lot relative to realizeds
@MayankSeksaria @michaelsantoli @BullandBaird @conorsen Who is buying? Retail? Institutions? I'm not seeing any pitches on vol, just comments about $XIV from time to time
@MayankSeksaria @michaelsantoli @BullandBaird @conorsen You would expect to see compression if the story is driven by vol selling since it hits implieds directly and may or may not hit realizeds
@MayankSeksaria @michaelsantoli @BullandBaird @conorsen Tho to the extent systematic selling of vol is happening, it does set you up for trouble. Where is all the vol selling happening & by who?
@MayankSeksaria @michaelsantoli @BullandBaird @conorsen This is what I'd expect. And selling vol operates directly on implieds. For realizeds 2b declining in step, something else has 2b going on
@MayankSeksaria @michaelsantoli @BullandBaird @conorsen Hard 2imagine systematic vol selling increasing the spread, so fact that realized so far below implied suggests not primarily vol selling
@MayankSeksaria @michaelsantoli @BullandBaird @conorsen Why would structural vol selling affect realized vol any more than implied vol? I'd think spread between implied & realized would compress
